data.title: UI rendered VERY LARGE

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Linux, Debian sid 64 bit.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start vscode via CLI or launcher.

Observed behavior:

After a recent update, vscode started rendering itself as though it thinks my environment's DPI is much higher than it actually is. A similar problem affects Chrome and Chromium. The workaround for those applications is to start them with the `--force-device-scale-factor` option. The same workaround with vscode, i.e.

````
$ code --force-device-scale-factor
````
gets everything but the menu bar back to where it should be. With the workaround, the menubar is shrunk.  The app is usable with this workaround, but it would be nice if the workaround wasn't needed.

No errors are reported in the app or on the console.

For completeness,
```
$ xdpyinfo | grep resolution
  resolution:    96x96 dots per inch
```
I am attaching two screenshots of my 1600x900 screen, one using the workaround and the other not.  Both were taken with vscode maximized.

![vscode-noworkaround](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2021060/25731839/7674875a-310f-11e7-8f0d-c413933a245b.png)
![vscode-workaround](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2021060/25731848/83ef0220-310f-11e7-8412-09c2678d8cb0.png)

data.title: [themes] Text selection color (find, search, etc)
data.body:
All input box based widgets (find, file search, etc) need text selection foreground/background
UI colors.

Have to decide if there should be a global ::selection color or any individual ones are needed.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25272315/25731617/bc049d7c-3115-11e7-9800-1c6954df6a99.png)

data.title: UI Theme Add: select-box(drop downs) selection and hover colors

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently all widgets using 'select-box' cannot theme
the selected or hover item colors (foreground/background)
The the color is controlled by the platform. That overrides
normal CSS approaches/selectors. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25272315/25731445/6cae4c38-3114-11e7-9400-254c525693ea.png)

After a bunch of research, I did figure out one solution
and made a prototype in a small electron app.

There appear to be three options:

1 - Some CSS guru knows of a better trick
2 - Use an input box on top of the current list widget 
3 - Use something like I came up with: 

   one select box that is the normal drop-down with current selection
   automatically includes the drop-down arrow
   a second select box which can be made hidden/visible depending
   on the first lightbox focus/selection

   The second select box can be styled with option:checked and box shadow

   
option:checked {
    color: #ffffff;
    box-shadow: 0 0 10px 100px #905000 inset;
}

    This box-shadow is the only thing I found that overwrites the platform colors
    It does NOT work on a select box with only one item showing (nominal case)
    That is what I came up with the two boxes and a bit of code to display and hide
    the second box with the options list

I think option two is more complicated and inherits the unneeded list properties
if there is no option one , I would go ahead and prototype within VSC and do a PR

Thoughts ?


![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25272315/25732059/b459145a-3119-11e7-89d5-9125c4a6f9f4.png)

I read the Official documents [https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/codebasics#_multiple-selections-multicursor](url) , but I just find how to make multiple cursor.

data.title: TypeScript: Unable to type class constructor with destructured params
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

```
//@ts-check

class Thing {

  /**
   * @param {Object} obj
   * @param {string} obj.param
   */
  constructor({ param }) {

  }

}
```
```
//@ts-check

class Thing {

  /**
   * @param {string} param
   */
  constructor({ param }) {

  }

}
```

The param: string typing is not enforced or hinted

data.title: TypeScript: Tooltip not registering recursive type
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

Hi everyone, I'm pretty new to TS and this latest VS Code update is getting me super excited about it and JSDoc!

- VSCode Version: 1.12.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:
```
//@ts-check

/**
 * @typedef RecursiveObject
 * @type {Object}
 * @property {RecursiveObject|object} children
 */

/**
 * @constructor
 * @param {RecursiveObject} param
 */
function Thing(param){};
```

I would expect the Thing type hint to say:
`Thing(param: { children: object | RecursiveObject; }): void`
but it says
`Thing(param: { children: object | any; }): void`

The good news is the typing is still enforced. e.g.

`let p = new Thing({ children: "bogo" })` gives a typing error

data.body:
_From @Gaffney on May 4, 2017 23:46_

My VSCode was working fine and was in a happy state.

Now after updating, every time I open a Go file or make a change in a Go file I get the popup:
`vscode "Cannot find "go" binary. Update PATH or GOROOT appropriately"`.

But go is on the path (in `/usr/local/bin`, which contains the symlink: `go -> ../Cellar/go/1.8.1/bin/go`), verified via the built-in terminal in VSCode:
```
gaffney:repo.git gaffney$ which go
/usr/local/bin/go
```
----------
- **Mac OSX**: 10.12
- **VSCode**: 1.12
- **vscode-go**: 0.6.60

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-go#965_

data.title: GitHub credentials aren't saved when prompted from vs code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12
- OS Version: Win10
- Git Version: 2.11.1 then 2.12.2

This was first reported to https://github.com/Microsoft/Git-Credential-Manager-for-Windows/issues/421 but is being cross posted here since it's unclear if the issue is coming from VS Code or the Git Credential Manager.

What's happening is the GCM keeps prompting me to login to GitHub and even when I do the credentials aren't saved to the Windows Credential Manager. I can repeatedly enter them and I'll continue to be prompted to login. Even hitting cancel no longer fully dismisses the prompt because in about 60 seconds it comes back. If I enter my login info to the GCM via the command prompt then they're stored and I'm no longer prompted when opening Code, but if I'm prompted from in Code then they aren't saved.

data.title: CodeLens increments references every time a file editor is opened
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

0. Apply setting: `"typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled": true`
1. Export TypeScript functions or classes, eg. `export function foo(): void {}`, from a .ts file.
2. Close and open said file.
3. Watch references increase by the actual number of references each time the file is opened, eg. if referenced twice, the count jumps 2, 4, 6, 8, etc.

* Same behavior was seen with an exported class.
* The export must be used somewhere else in order to trigger the behavior. If never used, the reference counts correctly stay at 0.
* When you click on the number of references, the CodeLens modal displays the correct count.

**Potentially useful info:**
* Global TypeScript 2.3.2
* tsconfig.json:
```
{
  "files": [
    "src/index.ts"
  ],
  "compilerOptions": {
    "inlineSourceMap": true,
    "lib": ["es2017"],
    "module": "commonjs",
    "noImplicitAny": false,
    "outDir": "./dist",
    "sourceMap": false,
    "target": "es6"
  }
}
```
* Happens even when `/dist` dir is empty.
* Behavior occurs when no extensions are active.
* Counts reset if you reload VS Code.

**Example:**

First time the file is opened:
![2refs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5186335/25729486/2d64bda0-30fb-11e7-9d6f-3e54836a637c.png)

No changes made.

Same file is closed then reopened:
![4refs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5186335/25729489/2f4f542c-30fb-11e7-9eb1-3ca3deaba041.png)

But the CodeLens modal shows the correct number of references:
![correct-modal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5186335/25729749/0a0c573a-30fd-11e7-8333-08809dc64be7.png)

---

I've never debugged VS Code before so I'm not sure what else is useful. Happy to dig in deeper if you need more info!

data.title: editorScroll command should support "left", "right" by "character"
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.x
- OS Version: Linux

The `editorScroll` command should support scrolling horizontally, not just vertically, by one or more characters.

data.title: VSCode, PlatformIO and AVR: Header files not resolved correctly
data.body:
VSCode Insider Version 1.12.0-insider (1.12.0-insider)

Hi,

trying to use VSCode together with PlatformIO and Atmel framework AVR. Generally ok.

Even though there is a path to the right include headers configured and recognised (ALT-CLICK opens the .h file), there is a problem. Several symbols are underlined in red. The tooltip says "Identifier xxx is undefined". Pressing ALT while hovering an additional entry offers "Click to view/show xxx definitions". 

The reason is that the appropriate ATTiny header file cannot be included directly, but needs to be "bootstrapped" (as suggested by AVR) by

`#include <avr/io.h>
`

from where the proper header is included by e.g.

```
#elif defined (__AVR_ATmega16U2__)
#  include <avr/iom16u2.h>
...
```

Obviously VSCode is unable to follow this deep link and it marks the definitions red. Including the proper platform file into the source doesn't work, because compilation fails with

`#error "Attempt to include more than one <avr/ioXXX.h> file."
`

due to a previous macro definition in io.h

How can I recover from this?

data.title: cursorMove to viewPortBottom should not scroll
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.x
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Execute the 'cursorMove' command with the following args
```js
{
  to: "viewPortBottom",
  select: false,
  by: "line",
  value: 1
}
```
2. Observe that the cursor moves to the bottom of the editor window and scrolls down one line

The editor should never scroll when `to` is "viewPortBottom" or "viewPortTop", but it does.

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Try any VSCode built-in C# snippet (ctor, prop etc)
2. Intellisense does not show the snippet in the list of available actions

data.title: Ctrl + mouse scroll zoom in & out
data.body: Could we please have Ctrl + mouse scroll increase and decrease text size as it does with most other (Windows) applications. At least in the Windows releases.

data.title: View is flickering when scrolling
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open  Code
2. Start scrolling

The complete view is flickering when scrolling. 
Happens since the update to 1.12

data.title: release notes should include browser link to online copy
data.body:
VS Code release notes open in webview, which is annoying for people wanting a normal browse experience. Every release note edition in the future should include a link to online copy we can open in a full featured browser. 

(I'd prefer the web view didn't open at all, it only ticks me because of it's limitations, but that's asking for too much)


- VSCode Version: 1.12
- OS Version: only 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. upgrade VS Code

data.title: Capfile isn't displayed as Ruby
data.body:
Open a Capfile (Capistrano) file. It's treated as plain text, but it should be Ruby.

- VSCode Version:  1.12.0 (1.12.0)
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.4 (16E195)
